doc_title: 1. Yoshua Bengio: Debating AI Safety Risks
claim: Even if a scalable technical solution to AI alignment existed, political and institutional failures — the coordination problem — mean no single country, corporation, or individual should be allowed to wield AGI power unilaterally; without robust multilateral governance we risk catastrophic abuse of AGI for oppression, geopolitical domination or economic capture.
explanation: Largely accurate. Academic and policy literature identifies “coordination failures” as a central governance problem for powerful AI—even if a technical alignment fix existed—because states, firms, and actors can race, defect, or weaponize capabilities absent credible multilateral rules. Research agendas and game‑theoretic analyses emphasise cooperation failures and strategic risk in transformative AI. ([governance.ai](https://www.governance.ai/research-paper/agenda?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.07228?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Empirical evidence shows current AI is already being used for repression, surveillance and political influence, illustrating how concentrated capability can enable abuse. ([hrw.org](https://www.hrw.org/report/2019/05/01/chinas-algorithms-repression/reverse-engineering-xinjiang-police-mass?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [freedomhouse.org](https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-net/2023/repressive-power-artificial-intelligence?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Major international bodies and many experts therefore call for multilateral governance, global guardrails, or dedicated institutions (e.g., proposals like MAGIC and UN/OECD initiatives) because voluntary or unilateral controls are judged insufficient to prevent oppression, geopolitical domination, or economic capture. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2310.20563?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [un.org](https://www.un.org/sg/en/content/sg/speeches/2024-05-21/secretary-generals-remarks-the-ai-seoul-summit-%E2%80%9Cbuilding-the-ai-safety-summit-towards-innovative-and-inclusive-future%E2%80%9D%C2%A0?utm_source=chatgpt.com), [oecd.org](https://www.oecd.org/en/topics/sub-issues/ai-principles.html?utm_source=chatgpt.com)) Given remaining uncertainties about exact modalities and political feasibility, this is not a certain prediction but a well‑supported and widely endorsed risk assessment and policy prescription.
